What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained an overview of fundamental principles in quantum mechanics and how those principles were first derived.

I learned how to think in terms of quantum mechanical effects. I now understand the foundational examples in quantum mechanics, including the free particle, particle in a box, and simple harmonic oscillator systems. I am also comfortable with operator notation and how to represent the theorems and postulates of quantum mechanics.
Schrdinger equation, operators, wavefunctions, particle in a box, harmonic oscillator, particle in a rectangular well
The Schrodinger equation, particle in a box model, operators, harmonic oscillator model, theorems/postulates of quantum mechanics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I honestly think almost every current aspect of this course is done well, from the lectures to the homework to preparation for the exam. I think the only thing which could be improved is providing more opportunities to get help-such as more office hours with Prof. Hammes-Schiffer or a discussion section with the TF.

The biggest strength for the course is the professor's engagement, ability to convey clearly, and immense knowledge of the subject.  Where this course was potentially lacking is in understanding what the exam would consist of, seen as the problem sets were very "plug and chug", and the exam was much more conceptual.  Overall, an excellent course.

This course has many strengths: straightforward notes that are closely related to the book, thorough mathematical descriptions of the problems without getting too bogged down in class-long derivations, in-class demos and labs to help students understand the concepts, and a homework difficulty that strikes a good balance. 

The only improvement I can think of would be to share the midterm review sheet at the beginning of the semester so that students can start becoming familiar with it and referencing it on the homework. It is a very good, concise resource that helped me organize and contextualize all the concepts when studying.

Slides are posted before class and include a couple in-class questions that are reviewed and updated on the slides after class, problem sets are from questions in the book so the related material is easy to access, Professor Hammes-Schiffer cares about students' understanding and is very approachable. The only improvement could potentially be including a few more visuals in class, but this might be more applicable to the material in the next half-semester course anyway.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course is a fantastic chemistry elective to take regardless of your interests within the major simply because of how well-structured the class is.
Yes, this course thoroughly covers topics that many other classes rely on. It's a great way to learn the basics of quantum mechanics.
Yes. Great introduction to quantum mechanics.

Yes, the material so far has been very similar to that covered in the second semester of Pchem and Sharon is a kind/helpful instructor that seems to really care about our learning of the material more than anything else!
